lines.speaker: LUCENTIO
lines.text: And what of him, Tranio?

lines.speaker: TRANIO
lines.text:
If he be credulous and trust my tale,
I'll make him glad to seem Vincentio,
And give assurance to Baptista Minola,
As if he were the right Vincentio
Take in your love, and then let me alone.
Exeunt LUCENTIO and BIANCA
Pedant
God save you, sir!

lines.speaker: TRANIO
lines.text:
And you, sir! you are welcome.
Travel you far on, or are you at the farthest?
Pedant
Sir, at the farthest for a week or two:
But then up farther, and as for as Rome;
And so to Tripoli, if God lend me life.

lines.speaker: TRANIO
lines.text:
What countryman, I pray?
Pedant
Of Mantua.

lines.speaker: TRANIO
lines.text:
Of Mantua, sir? marry, God forbid!
And come to Padua, careless of your life?
Pedant
My life, sir! how, I pray? for that goes hard.

lines.speaker: TRANIO
lines.text:
'Tis death for any one in Mantua
To come to Padua. Know you not the cause?
Your ships are stay'd at Venice, and the duke,
For private quarrel 'twixt your duke and him,
Hath publish'd and proclaim'd it openly:
'Tis, marvel, but that you are but newly come,
You might have heard it else proclaim'd about.
Pedant
Alas! sir, it is worse for me than so;
For I have bills for money by exchange
From Florence and must here deliver them.

lines.speaker: TRANIO
lines.text:
Well, sir, to do you courtesy,
This will I do, and this I will advise you:
First, tell me, have you ever been at Pisa?
Pedant
Ay, sir, in Pisa have I often been,
Pisa renowned for grave citizens.

lines.speaker: TRANIO
lines.text:
Among them know you one Vincentio?
Pedant
I know him not, but I have heard of him;
A merchant of incomparable wealth.

lines.speaker: TRANIO
lines.text:
He is my father, sir; and, sooth to say,
In countenance somewhat doth resemble you.

lines.speaker: BIONDELLO
lines.text:
[Aside] As much as an apple doth an oyster,
and all one.

lines.speaker: TRANIO
lines.text:
To save your life in this extremity,
This favour will I do you for his sake;
And think it not the worst of an your fortunes
That you are like to Sir Vincentio.
His name and credit shall you undertake,
And in my house you shall be friendly lodged:
Look that you take upon you as you should;
You understand me, sir: so shall you stay
Till you have done your business in the city:
If this be courtesy, sir, accept of it.
Pedant
O sir, I do; and will repute you ever
The patron of my life and liberty.

lines.speaker: TRANIO
lines.text:
Then go with me to make the matter good.
This, by the way, I let you understand;
my father is here look'd for every day,
To pass assurance of a dower in marriage
'Twixt me and one Baptista's daughter here:
In all these circumstances I'll instruct you:
Go with me to clothe you as becomes you.
Exeunt

lines.speaker: GRUMIO
lines.text: No, no, forsooth; I dare not for my life.

lines.speaker: KATHARINA
lines.text:
The more my wrong, the more his spite appears:
What, did he marry me to famish me?
Beggars, that come unto my father's door,
Upon entreaty have a present aims;
If not, elsewhere they meet with charity:
But I, who never knew how to entreat,
Nor never needed that I should entreat,
Am starved for meat, giddy for lack of sleep,
With oath kept waking and with brawling fed:
And that which spites me more than all these wants,
He does it under name of perfect love;
As who should say, if I should sleep or eat,
'Twere deadly sickness or else present death.
I prithee go and get me some repast;
I care not what, so it be wholesome food.

lines.speaker: GRUMIO
lines.text: What say you to a neat's foot?

lines.speaker: KATHARINA
lines.text: 'Tis passing good: I prithee let me have it.

lines.speaker: GRUMIO
lines.text:
I fear it is too choleric a meat.
How say you to a fat tripe finely broil'd?

lines.speaker: KATHARINA
lines.text: I like it well: good Grumio, fetch it me.

lines.speaker: GRUMIO
lines.text:
I cannot tell; I fear 'tis choleric.
What say you to a piece of beef and mustard?

lines.speaker: KATHARINA
lines.text: A dish that I do love to feed upon.

lines.speaker: GRUMIO
lines.text: Ay, but the mustard is too hot a little.

lines.speaker: KATHARINA
lines.text: Why then, the beef, and let the mustard rest.

lines.speaker: GRUMIO
lines.text:
Nay then, I will not: you shall have the mustard,
Or else you get no beef of Grumio.

lines.speaker: KATHARINA
lines.text: Then both, or one, or any thing thou wilt.

lines.speaker: GRUMIO
lines.text: Why then, the mustard without the beef.

lines.speaker: KATHARINA
lines.text:
Go, get thee gone, thou false deluding slave,
Beats him
That feed'st me with the very name of meat:
Sorrow on thee and all the pack of you,
That triumph thus upon my misery!
Go, get thee gone, I say.

lines.speaker: PETRUCHIO
lines.text: How fares my Kate? What, sweeting, all amort?

lines.speaker: HORTENSIO
lines.text: Mistress, what cheer?

lines.speaker: KATHARINA
lines.text: Faith, as cold as can be.

lines.speaker: PETRUCHIO
lines.text:
Pluck up thy spirits; look cheerfully upon me.
Here love; thou see'st how diligent I am
To dress thy meat myself and bring it thee:
I am sure, sweet Kate, this kindness merits thanks.
What, not a word? Nay, then thou lovest it not;
And all my pains is sorted to no proof.
Here, take away this dish.

lines.speaker: KATHARINA
lines.text: I pray you, let it stand.

lines.speaker: PETRUCHIO
lines.text:
The poorest service is repaid with thanks;
And so shall mine, before you touch the meat.

lines.speaker: KATHARINA
lines.text: I thank you, sir.

lines.speaker: HORTENSIO
lines.text:
Signior Petruchio, fie! you are to blame.
Come, mistress Kate, I'll bear you company.

lines.speaker: PETRUCHIO
lines.text:
[Aside] Eat it up all, Hortensio, if thou lovest me.
Much good do it unto thy gentle heart!
Kate, eat apace: and now, my honey love,
Will we return unto thy father's house
And revel it as bravely as the best,
With silken coats and caps and golden rings,
With ruffs and cuffs and fardingales and things;
With scarfs and fans and double change of bravery,
With amber bracelets, beads and all this knavery.
What, hast thou dined? The tailor stays thy leisure,
To deck thy body with his ruffling treasure.
Come, tailor, let us see these ornaments;
Lay forth the gown.
What news with you, sir?
Haberdasher
Here is the cap your worship did bespeak.

lines.speaker: PETRUCHIO
lines.text:
Why, this was moulded on a porringer;
A velvet dish: fie, fie! 'tis lewd and filthy:
Why, 'tis a cockle or a walnut-shell,
A knack, a toy, a trick, a baby's cap:
Away with it! come, let me have a bigger.

lines.speaker: KATHARINA
lines.text:
I'll have no bigger: this doth fit the time,
And gentlewomen wear such caps as these

lines.speaker: PETRUCHIO
lines.text:
When you are gentle, you shall have one too,
And not till then.

lines.speaker: HORTENSIO
lines.text: [Aside] That will not be in haste.

lines.speaker: KATHARINA
lines.text:
Why, sir, I trust I may have leave to speak;
And speak I will; I am no child, no babe:
Your betters have endured me say my mind,
And if you cannot, best you stop your ears.
My tongue will tell the anger of my heart,
Or else my heart concealing it will break,
And rather than it shall, I will be free
Even to the uttermost, as I please, in words.

lines.speaker: PETRUCHIO
lines.text:
Why, thou say'st true; it is a paltry cap,
A custard-coffin, a bauble, a silken pie:
I love thee well, in that thou likest it not.

lines.speaker: KATHARINA
lines.text:
Love me or love me not, I like the cap;
And it I will have, or I will have none.

lines.speaker: PETRUCHIO
lines.text:
Thy gown? why, ay: come, tailor, let us see't.
O mercy, God! what masquing stuff is here?
What's this? a sleeve? 'tis like a demi-cannon:
What, up and down, carved like an apple-tart?
Here's snip and nip and cut and slish and slash,
Like to a censer in a barber's shop:
Why, what, i' devil's name, tailor, call'st thou this?

lines.speaker: HORTENSIO
lines.text:
[Aside] I see she's like to have neither cap nor gown.
Tailor
You bid me make it orderly and well,
According to the fashion and the time.

lines.speaker: PETRUCHIO
lines.text:
Marry, and did; but if you be remember'd,
I did not bid you mar it to the time.
Go, hop me over every kennel home,
For you shall hop without my custom, sir:
I'll none of it: hence! make your best of it.

lines.speaker: KATHARINA
lines.text:
I never saw a better-fashion'd gown,
More quaint, more pleasing, nor more commendable:
Belike you mean to make a puppet of me.

lines.speaker: PETRUCHIO
lines.text:
Why, true; he means to make a puppet of thee.
Tailor
She says your worship means to make
a puppet of her.

lines.speaker: PETRUCHIO
lines.text:
O monstrous arrogance! Thou liest, thou thread,
thou thimble,
Thou yard, three-quarters, half-yard, quarter, nail!
Thou flea, thou nit, thou winter-cricket thou!
Braved in mine own house with a skein of thread?
Away, thou rag, thou quantity, thou remnant;
Or I shall so be-mete thee with thy yard
As thou shalt think on prating whilst thou livest!
I tell thee, I, that thou hast marr'd her gown.
Tailor
Your worship is deceived; the gown is made
Just as my master had direction:
Grumio gave order how it should be done.

lines.speaker: GRUMIO
lines.text:
I gave him no order; I gave him the stuff.
Tailor
But how did you desire it should be made?

lines.speaker: GRUMIO
lines.text:
Marry, sir, with needle and thread.
Tailor
But did you not request to have it cut?

lines.speaker: GRUMIO
lines.text:
Thou hast faced many things.
Tailor
I have.

lines.speaker: GRUMIO
lines.text:
Face not me: thou hast braved many men; brave not
me; I will neither be faced nor braved. I say unto
thee, I bid thy master cut out the gown; but I did
not bid him cut it to pieces: ergo, thou liest.
Tailor
Why, here is the note of the fashion to testify

lines.speaker: PETRUCHIO
lines.text: Read it.

lines.speaker: GRUMIO
lines.text:
The note lies in's throat, if he say I said so.
Tailor
[Reads] 'Imprimis, a loose-bodied gown:'

lines.speaker: GRUMIO
lines.text:
Master, if ever I said loose-bodied gown, sew me in
the skirts of it, and beat me to death with a bottom
of brown thread: I said a gown.

lines.speaker: PETRUCHIO
lines.text:
Proceed.
Tailor
[Reads] 'With a small compassed cape:'

lines.speaker: GRUMIO
lines.text:
I confess the cape.
Tailor
[Reads] 'With a trunk sleeve:'

lines.speaker: GRUMIO
lines.text:
I confess two sleeves.
Tailor
[Reads] 'The sleeves curiously cut.'

lines.speaker: PETRUCHIO
lines.text: Ay, there's the villany.

lines.speaker: GRUMIO
lines.text:
Error i' the bill, sir; error i' the bill.
I commanded the sleeves should be cut out and
sewed up again; and that I'll prove upon thee,
though thy little finger be armed in a thimble.
Tailor
This is true that I say: an I had thee
in place where, thou shouldst know it.

lines.speaker: GRUMIO
lines.text:
I am for thee straight: take thou the
bill, give me thy mete-yard, and spare not me.

lines.speaker: HORTENSIO
lines.text: God-a-mercy, Grumio! then he shall have no odds.

lines.speaker: PETRUCHIO
lines.text: Well, sir, in brief, the gown is not for me.

lines.speaker: GRUMIO
lines.text: You are i' the right, sir: 'tis for my mistress.

lines.speaker: PETRUCHIO
lines.text: Go, take it up unto thy master's use.

lines.speaker: GRUMIO
lines.text:
Villain, not for thy life: take up my mistress'
gown for thy master's use!

lines.speaker: PETRUCHIO
lines.text: Why, sir, what's your conceit in that?

lines.speaker: GRUMIO
lines.text:
O, sir, the conceit is deeper than you think for:
Take up my mistress' gown to his master's use!
O, fie, fie, fie!

lines.speaker: PETRUCHIO
lines.text:
[Aside] Hortensio, say thou wilt see the tailor paid.
Go take it hence; be gone, and say no more.

lines.speaker: HORTENSIO
lines.text:
Tailor, I'll pay thee for thy gown tomorrow:
Take no unkindness of his hasty words:
Away! I say; commend me to thy master.

lines.speaker: PETRUCHIO
lines.text:
Well, come, my Kate; we will unto your father's
Even in these honest mean habiliments:
Our purses shall be proud, our garments poor;
For 'tis the mind that makes the body rich;
And as the sun breaks through the darkest clouds,
So honour peereth in the meanest habit.
What is the jay more precious than the lark,
Because his fathers are more beautiful?
Or is the adder better than the eel,
Because his painted skin contents the eye?
O, no, good Kate; neither art thou the worse
For this poor furniture and mean array.
if thou account'st it shame. lay it on me;
And therefore frolic: we will hence forthwith,
To feast and sport us at thy father's house.
Go, call my men, and let us straight to him;
And bring our horses unto Long-lane end;
There will we mount, and thither walk on foot
Let's see; I think 'tis now some seven o'clock,
And well we may come there by dinner-time.

lines.speaker: KATHARINA
lines.text:
I dare assure you, sir, 'tis almost two;
And 'twill be supper-time ere you come there.

lines.speaker: PETRUCHIO
lines.text:
It shall be seven ere I go to horse:
Look, what I speak, or do, or think to do,
You are still crossing it. Sirs, let't alone:
I will not go to-day; and ere I do,
It shall be what o'clock I say it is.

lines.speaker: HORTENSIO
lines.text:
[Aside] Why, so this gallant will command the sun.
Exeunt

lines.speaker: TRANIO
lines.text:
Sir, this is the house: please it you that I call?
Pedant
Ay, what else? and but I be deceived
Signior Baptista may remember me,
Near twenty years ago, in Genoa,
Where we were lodgers at the Pegasus.

lines.speaker: TRANIO
lines.text:
'Tis well; and hold your own, in any case,
With such austerity as 'longeth to a father.
Pedant
I warrant you.
But, sir, here comes your boy;
'Twere good he were school'd.

lines.speaker: TRANIO
lines.text:
Fear you not him. Sirrah Biondello,
Now do your duty throughly, I advise you:
Imagine 'twere the right Vincentio.

lines.speaker: BIONDELLO
lines.text: Tut, fear not me.

lines.speaker: TRANIO
lines.text: But hast thou done thy errand to Baptista?

lines.speaker: BIONDELLO
lines.text:
I told him that your father was at Venice,
And that you look'd for him this day in Padua.

lines.speaker: TRANIO
lines.text:
Thou'rt a tall fellow: hold thee that to drink.
Here comes Baptista: set your countenance, sir.
Signior Baptista, you are happily met.
To the Pedant
Sir, this is the gentleman I told you of:
I pray you stand good father to me now,
Give me Bianca for my patrimony.
Pedant
Soft son!
Sir, by your leave: having come to Padua
To gather in some debts, my son Lucentio
Made me acquainted with a weighty cause
Of love between your daughter and himself:
And, for the good report I hear of you
And for the love he beareth to your daughter
And she to him, to stay him not too long,
I am content, in a good father's care,
To have him match'd; and if you please to like
No worse than I, upon some agreement
Me shall you find ready and willing
With one consent to have her so bestow'd;
For curious I cannot be with you,
Signior Baptista, of whom I hear so well.

lines.speaker: BAPTISTA
lines.text:
Sir, pardon me in what I have to say:
Your plainness and your shortness please me well.
Right true it is, your son Lucentio here
Doth love my daughter and she loveth him,
Or both dissemble deeply their affections:
And therefore, if you say no more than this,
That like a father you will deal with him
And pass my daughter a sufficient dower,
The match is made, and all is done:
Your son shall have my daughter with consent.

lines.speaker: TRANIO
lines.text:
I thank you, sir. Where then do you know best
We be affied and such assurance ta'en
As shall with either part's agreement stand?

lines.speaker: BAPTISTA
lines.text:
Not in my house, Lucentio; for, you know,
Pitchers have ears, and I have many servants:
Besides, old Gremio is hearkening still;
And happily we might be interrupted.

lines.speaker: TRANIO
lines.text:
Then at my lodging, an it like you:
There doth my father lie; and there, this night,
We'll pass the business privately and well.
Send for your daughter by your servant here:
My boy shall fetch the scrivener presently.
The worst is this, that, at so slender warning,
You are like to have a thin and slender pittance.

lines.speaker: BAPTISTA
lines.text:
It likes me well. Biondello, hie you home,
And bid Bianca make her ready straight;
And, if you will, tell what hath happened,
Lucentio's father is arrived in Padua,
And how she's like to be Lucentio's wife.

lines.speaker: BIONDELLO
lines.text: I pray the gods she may with all my heart!

lines.speaker: TRANIO
lines.text:
Dally not with the gods, but get thee gone.
Signior Baptista, shall I lead the way?
Welcome! one mess is like to be your cheer:
Come, sir; we will better it in Pisa.

lines.speaker: BAPTISTA
lines.text:
I follow you.
Exeunt TRANIO, Pedant, and BAPTISTA

lines.speaker: BIONDELLO
lines.text: Cambio!

lines.speaker: LUCENTIO
lines.text: What sayest thou, Biondello?

lines.speaker: BIONDELLO
lines.text: You saw my master wink and laugh upon you?

lines.speaker: LUCENTIO
lines.text: Biondello, what of that?

lines.speaker: BIONDELLO
lines.text:
Faith, nothing; but has left me here behind, to
expound the meaning or moral of his signs and tokens.

lines.speaker: LUCENTIO
lines.text: I pray thee, moralize them.

lines.speaker: BIONDELLO
lines.text:
Then thus. Baptista is safe, talking with the
deceiving father of a deceitful son.

lines.speaker: LUCENTIO
lines.text: And what of him?

lines.speaker: BIONDELLO
lines.text: His daughter is to be brought by you to the supper.

lines.speaker: LUCENTIO
lines.text: And then?

lines.speaker: BIONDELLO
lines.text:
The old priest of Saint Luke's church is at your
command at all hours.

lines.speaker: LUCENTIO
lines.text: And what of all this?

lines.speaker: BIONDELLO
lines.text:
I cannot tell; expect they are busied about a
counterfeit assurance: take you assurance of her,
'cum privilegio ad imprimendum solum:' to the
church; take the priest, clerk, and some sufficient
honest witnesses: If this be not that you look for,
I have no more to say, But bid Bianca farewell for
ever and a day.

lines.speaker: LUCENTIO
lines.text: Hearest thou, Biondello?

lines.speaker: BIONDELLO
lines.text:
I cannot tarry: I knew a wench married in an
afternoon as she went to the garden for parsley to
stuff a rabbit; and so may you, sir: and so, adieu,
sir. My master hath appointed me to go to Saint
Luke's, to bid the priest be ready to come against
you come with your appendix.

lines.speaker: LUCENTIO
lines.text:
I may, and will, if she be so contented:
She will be pleased; then wherefore should I doubt?
Hap what hap may, I'll roundly go about her:
It shall go hard if Cambio go without her.

lines.speaker: PETRUCHIO
lines.text:
Come on, i' God's name; once more toward our father's.
Good Lord, how bright and goodly shines the moon!

lines.speaker: KATHARINA
lines.text: The moon! the sun: it is not moonlight now.

lines.speaker: PETRUCHIO
lines.text: I say it is the moon that shines so bright.

lines.speaker: KATHARINA
lines.text: I know it is the sun that shines so bright.

lines.speaker: PETRUCHIO
lines.text:
Now, by my mother's son, and that's myself,
It shall be moon, or star, or what I list,
Or ere I journey to your father's house.
Go on, and fetch our horses back again.
Evermore cross'd and cross'd; nothing but cross'd!

lines.speaker: HORTENSIO
lines.text: Say as he says, or we shall never go.

lines.speaker: KATHARINA
lines.text:
Forward, I pray, since we have come so far,
And be it moon, or sun, or what you please:
An if you please to call it a rush-candle,
Henceforth I vow it shall be so for me.

lines.speaker: PETRUCHIO
lines.text: I say it is the moon.

lines.speaker: KATHARINA
lines.text: I know it is the moon.

lines.speaker: PETRUCHIO
lines.text: Nay, then you lie: it is the blessed sun.

lines.speaker: KATHARINA
HORTENSIO
lines.text: Petruchio, go thy ways; the field is won.

lines.speaker: PETRUCHIO
lines.text:
Well, forward, forward! thus the bowl should run,
And not unluckily against the bias.
But, soft! company is coming here.
To VINCENTIO
Good morrow, gentle mistress: where away?
Tell me, sweet Kate, and tell me truly too,
Hast thou beheld a fresher gentlewoman?
Such war of white and red within her cheeks!
What stars do spangle heaven with such beauty,
As those two eyes become that heavenly face?
Fair lovely maid, once more good day to thee.
Sweet Kate, embrace her for her beauty's sake.

lines.speaker: HORTENSIO
lines.text: A' will make the man mad, to make a woman of him.

lines.speaker: KATHARINA
lines.text:
Young budding virgin, fair and fresh and sweet,
Whither away, or where is thy abode?
Happy the parents of so fair a child;
Happier the man, whom favourable stars
Allot thee for his lovely bed-fellow!

lines.speaker: PETRUCHIO
lines.text:
Why, how now, Kate! I hope thou art not mad:
This is a man, old, wrinkled, faded, wither'd,
And not a maiden, as thou say'st he is.

lines.speaker: KATHARINA
lines.text:
Pardon, old father, my mistaking eyes,
That have been so bedazzled with the sun
That everything I look on seemeth green:
Now I perceive thou art a reverend father;
Pardon, I pray thee, for my mad mistaking.

lines.speaker: PETRUCHIO
lines.text:
Do, good old grandsire; and withal make known
Which way thou travellest: if along with us,
We shall be joyful of thy company.

lines.speaker: VINCENTIO
lines.text:
Fair sir, and you my merry mistress,
That with your strange encounter much amazed me,
My name is call'd Vincentio; my dwelling Pisa;
And bound I am to Padua; there to visit
A son of mine, which long I have not seen.

lines.speaker: PETRUCHIO
lines.text: What is his name?

lines.speaker: VINCENTIO
lines.text: Lucentio, gentle sir.

lines.speaker: PETRUCHIO
lines.text:
Happily we met; the happier for thy son.
And now by law, as well as reverend age,
I may entitle thee my loving father:
The sister to my wife, this gentlewoman,
Thy son by this hath married. Wonder not,
Nor be grieved: she is of good esteem,
Her dowery wealthy, and of worthy birth;
Beside, so qualified as may beseem
The spouse of any noble gentleman.
Let me embrace with old Vincentio,
And wander we to see thy honest son,
Who will of thy arrival be full joyous.

lines.speaker: VINCENTIO
lines.text:
But is it true? or else is it your pleasure,
Like pleasant travellers, to break a jest
Upon the company you overtake?

lines.speaker: HORTENSIO
lines.text: I do assure thee, father, so it is.

lines.speaker: PETRUCHIO
HORTENSIO
lines.text:
Well, Petruchio, this has put me in heart.
Have to my widow! and if she be froward,
Then hast thou taught Hortensio to be untoward.

lines.speaker: BIONDELLO
lines.text: Softly and swiftly, sir; for the priest is ready.

lines.speaker: LUCENTIO
lines.text:
I fly, Biondello: but they may chance to need thee
at home; therefore leave us.

lines.speaker: BIONDELLO
lines.text:
Nay, faith, I'll see the church o' your back; and
then come back to my master's as soon as I can.
Exeunt LUCENTIO, BIANCA, and BIONDELLO

lines.speaker: GREMIO
lines.text: I marvel Cambio comes not all this while.

lines.speaker: PETRUCHIO
VINCENTIO
lines.text:
You shall not choose but drink before you go:
I think I shall command your welcome here,
And, by all likelihood, some cheer is toward.
Knocks

lines.speaker: GREMIO
lines.text:
They're busy within; you were best knock louder.
Pedant looks out of the window
Pedant
What's he that knocks as he would beat down the gate?

lines.speaker: VINCENTIO
lines.text:
Is Signior Lucentio within, sir?
Pedant
He's within, sir, but not to be spoken withal.

lines.speaker: VINCENTIO
lines.text:
What if a man bring him a hundred pound or two, to
make merry withal?
Pedant
Keep your hundred pounds to yourself: he shall
need none, so long as I live.

lines.speaker: PETRUCHIO
lines.text:
Nay, I told you your son was well beloved in Padua.
Do you hear, sir? To leave frivolous circumstances,
I pray you, tell Signior Lucentio that his father is
come from Pisa, and is here at the door to speak with him.
Pedant
Thou liest: his father is come from Padua and here
looking out at the window.

lines.speaker: VINCENTIO
lines.text:
Art thou his father?
Pedant
Ay, sir; so his mother says, if I may believe her.

lines.speaker: PETRUCHIO
lines.text:
[To VINCENTIO] Why, how now, gentleman! why, this
is flat knavery, to take upon you another man's name.
Pedant
Lay hands on the villain: I believe a' means to
cozen somebody in this city under my countenance.

lines.speaker: BIONDELLO
lines.text:
I have seen them in the church together: God send
'em good shipping! But who is here? mine old
master Vincentio! now we are undone and brought to nothing.

lines.speaker: VINCENTIO
lines.text:
[Seeing BIONDELLO]
Come hither, crack-hemp.

lines.speaker: BIONDELLO
lines.text: Hope I may choose, sir.

lines.speaker: VINCENTIO
lines.text: Come hither, you rogue. What, have you forgot me?

lines.speaker: BIONDELLO
lines.text:
Forgot you! no, sir: I could not forget you, for I
never saw you before in all my life.

lines.speaker: VINCENTIO
lines.text:
What, you notorious villain, didst thou never see
thy master's father, Vincentio?

lines.speaker: BIONDELLO
lines.text:
What, my old worshipful old master? yes, marry, sir:
see where he looks out of the window.

lines.speaker: VINCENTIO
lines.text:
Is't so, indeed.
Beats BIONDELLO

lines.speaker: BIONDELLO
lines.text:
Help, help, help! here's a madman will murder me.
Pedant
Help, son! help, Signior Baptista!

lines.speaker: PETRUCHIO
lines.text:
Prithee, Kate, let's stand aside and see the end of
this controversy.
They retire

lines.speaker: TRANIO
lines.text: Sir, what are you that offer to beat my servant?

lines.speaker: VINCENTIO
lines.text:
What am I, sir! nay, what are you, sir? O immortal
gods! O fine villain! A silken doublet! a velvet
hose! a scarlet cloak! and a copatain hat! O, I
am undone! I am undone! while I play the good
husband at home, my son and my servant spend all at
the university.

lines.speaker: TRANIO
lines.text: How now! what's the matter?

lines.speaker: BAPTISTA
lines.text: What, is the man lunatic?

lines.speaker: TRANIO
lines.text:
Sir, you seem a sober ancient gentleman by your
habit, but your words show you a madman. Why, sir,
what 'cerns it you if I wear pearl and gold? I
thank my good father, I am able to maintain it.

lines.speaker: VINCENTIO
lines.text: Thy father! O villain! he is a sailmaker in Bergamo.

lines.speaker: BAPTISTA
lines.text:
You mistake, sir, you mistake, sir. Pray, what do
you think is his name?

lines.speaker: VINCENTIO
lines.text:
His name! as if I knew not his name: I have brought
him up ever since he was three years old, and his
name is Tranio.
Pedant
Away, away, mad ass! his name is Lucentio and he is
mine only son, and heir to the lands of me, Signior Vincentio.

lines.speaker: VINCENTIO
lines.text:
Lucentio! O, he hath murdered his master! Lay hold
on him, I charge you, in the duke's name. O, my
son, my son! Tell me, thou villain, where is my son Lucentio?

lines.speaker: TRANIO
lines.text:
Call forth an officer.
Carry this mad knave to the gaol. Father Baptista,
I charge you see that he be forthcoming.

lines.speaker: VINCENTIO
lines.text: Carry me to the gaol!

lines.speaker: GREMIO
lines.text: Stay, officer: he shall not go to prison.

lines.speaker: BAPTISTA
lines.text: Talk not, Signior Gremio: I say he shall go to prison.

lines.speaker: GREMIO
lines.text:
Take heed, Signior Baptista, lest you be
cony-catched in this business: I dare swear this
is the right Vincentio.
Pedant
Swear, if thou darest.

lines.speaker: GREMIO
lines.text: Nay, I dare not swear it.

lines.speaker: TRANIO
lines.text: Then thou wert best say that I am not Lucentio.

lines.speaker: GREMIO
lines.text: Yes, I know thee to be Signior Lucentio.

lines.speaker: BAPTISTA
lines.text: Away with the dotard! to the gaol with him!

lines.speaker: VINCENTIO
lines.text:
Thus strangers may be hailed and abused: O
monstrous villain!

lines.speaker: BIONDELLO
lines.text:
O! we are spoiled and--yonder he is: deny him,
forswear him, or else we are all undone.

lines.speaker: LUCENTIO
lines.text: [Kneeling] Pardon, sweet father.

lines.speaker: VINCENTIO
lines.text:
Lives my sweet son?
Exeunt BIONDELLO, TRANIO, and Pedant, as fast as may be

lines.speaker: BIANCA
lines.text: Pardon, dear father.

lines.speaker: BAPTISTA
lines.text:
How hast thou offended?
Where is Lucentio?

lines.speaker: LUCENTIO
lines.text:
Here's Lucentio,
Right son to the right Vincentio;
That have by marriage made thy daughter mine,
While counterfeit supposes bleared thine eyne.

lines.speaker: GREMIO
lines.text: Here's packing, with a witness to deceive us all!

lines.speaker: VINCENTIO
lines.text:
Where is that damned villain Tranio,
That faced and braved me in this matter so?

lines.speaker: BAPTISTA
lines.text: Why, tell me, is not this my Cambio?

lines.speaker: BIANCA
lines.text: Cambio is changed into Lucentio.

lines.speaker: LUCENTIO
lines.text:
Love wrought these miracles. Bianca's love
Made me exchange my state with Tranio,
While he did bear my countenance in the town;
And happily I have arrived at the last
Unto the wished haven of my bliss.
What Tranio did, myself enforced him to;
Then pardon him, sweet father, for my sake.

lines.speaker: VINCENTIO
lines.text:
I'll slit the villain's nose, that would have sent
me to the gaol.

lines.speaker: BAPTISTA
lines.text:
But do you hear, sir? have you married my daughter
without asking my good will?

lines.speaker: VINCENTIO
lines.text:
Fear not, Baptista; we will content you, go to: but
I will in, to be revenged for this villany.

lines.speaker: BAPTISTA
lines.text: And I, to sound the depth of this knavery.

lines.speaker: LUCENTIO
lines.text:
Look not pale, Bianca; thy father will not frown.
Exeunt LUCENTIO and BIANCA

lines.speaker: GREMIO
lines.text:
My cake is dough; but I'll in among the rest,
Out of hope of all, but my share of the feast.

lines.speaker: KATHARINA
lines.text: Husband, let's follow, to see the end of this ado.

lines.speaker: PETRUCHIO
lines.text: First kiss me, Kate, and we will.

lines.speaker: KATHARINA
lines.text: What, in the midst of the street?

lines.speaker: PETRUCHIO
lines.text: What, art thou ashamed of me?

lines.speaker: KATHARINA
lines.text: No, sir, God forbid; but ashamed to kiss.

lines.speaker: PETRUCHIO
lines.text: Why, then let's home again. Come, sirrah, let's away.

lines.speaker: KATHARINA
lines.text: Nay, I will give thee a kiss: now pray thee, love, stay.

lines.speaker: PETRUCHIO
lines.text:
Is not this well? Come, my sweet Kate:
Better once than never, for never too late.
Exeunt

lines.speaker: LUCENTIO
lines.text:
At last, though long, our jarring notes agree:
And time it is, when raging war is done,
To smile at scapes and perils overblown.
My fair Bianca, bid my father welcome,
While I with self-same kindness welcome thine.
Brother Petruchio, sister Katharina,
And thou, Hortensio, with thy loving widow,
Feast with the best, and welcome to my house:
My banquet is to close our stomachs up,
After our great good cheer. Pray you, sit down;
For now we sit to chat as well as eat.

lines.speaker: PETRUCHIO
lines.text: Nothing but sit and sit, and eat and eat!

lines.speaker: BAPTISTA
lines.text: Padua affords this kindness, son Petruchio.

lines.speaker: PETRUCHIO
lines.text: Padua affords nothing but what is kind.

lines.speaker: HORTENSIO
lines.text: For both our sakes, I would that word were true.

lines.speaker: PETRUCHIO
lines.text:
Now, for my life, Hortensio fears his widow.
Widow
Then never trust me, if I be afeard.

lines.speaker: PETRUCHIO
lines.text:
You are very sensible, and yet you miss my sense:
I mean, Hortensio is afeard of you.
Widow
He that is giddy thinks the world turns round.

lines.speaker: PETRUCHIO
lines.text: Roundly replied.

lines.speaker: KATHARINA
lines.text:
Mistress, how mean you that?
Widow
Thus I conceive by him.

lines.speaker: PETRUCHIO
lines.text: Conceives by me! How likes Hortensio that?

lines.speaker: HORTENSIO
lines.text: My widow says, thus she conceives her tale.

lines.speaker: PETRUCHIO
lines.text: Very well mended. Kiss him for that, good widow.

lines.speaker: KATHARINA
lines.text:
'He that is giddy thinks the world turns round:'
I pray you, tell me what you meant by that.
Widow
Your husband, being troubled with a shrew,
Measures my husband's sorrow by his woe:
And now you know my meaning,

lines.speaker: KATHARINA
lines.text:
A very mean meaning.
Widow
Right, I mean you.

lines.speaker: KATHARINA
lines.text: And I am mean indeed, respecting you.

lines.speaker: PETRUCHIO
lines.text: To her, Kate!

lines.speaker: HORTENSIO
lines.text: To her, widow!

lines.speaker: PETRUCHIO
lines.text: A hundred marks, my Kate does put her down.

lines.speaker: HORTENSIO
lines.text: That's my office.

lines.speaker: PETRUCHIO
lines.text:
Spoke like an officer; ha' to thee, lad!
Drinks to HORTENSIO

lines.speaker: BAPTISTA
lines.text: How likes Gremio these quick-witted folks?

lines.speaker: GREMIO
lines.text: Believe me, sir, they butt together well.

lines.speaker: BIANCA
lines.text:
Head, and butt! an hasty-witted body
Would say your head and butt were head and horn.

lines.speaker: VINCENTIO
lines.text: Ay, mistress bride, hath that awaken'd you?

lines.speaker: BIANCA
lines.text: Ay, but not frighted me; therefore I'll sleep again.

lines.speaker: PETRUCHIO
lines.text:
Nay, that you shall not: since you have begun,
Have at you for a bitter jest or two!

lines.speaker: BIANCA
lines.text:
Am I your bird? I mean to shift my bush;
And then pursue me as you draw your bow.
You are welcome all.
Exeunt BIANCA, KATHARINA, and Widow

lines.speaker: PETRUCHIO
TRANIO
lines.text:
O, sir, Lucentio slipp'd me like his greyhound,
Which runs himself and catches for his master.

lines.speaker: PETRUCHIO
lines.text: A good swift simile, but something currish.

lines.speaker: TRANIO
lines.text:
'Tis well, sir, that you hunted for yourself:
'Tis thought your deer does hold you at a bay.

lines.speaker: BAPTISTA
lines.text: O ho, Petruchio! Tranio hits you now.

lines.speaker: LUCENTIO
lines.text: I thank thee for that gird, good Tranio.

lines.speaker: HORTENSIO
lines.text: Confess, confess, hath he not hit you here?

lines.speaker: PETRUCHIO
BAPTISTA
lines.text:
Now, in good sadness, son Petruchio,
I think thou hast the veriest shrew of all.

lines.speaker: PETRUCHIO
lines.text:
Well, I say no: and therefore for assurance
Let's each one send unto his wife;
And he whose wife is most obedient
To come at first when he doth send for her,
Shall win the wager which we will propose.

lines.speaker: HORTENSIO
lines.text: Content. What is the wager?

lines.speaker: LUCENTIO
lines.text: Twenty crowns.

lines.speaker: PETRUCHIO
lines.text:
Twenty crowns!
I'll venture so much of my hawk or hound,
But twenty times so much upon my wife.

lines.speaker: LUCENTIO
lines.text: A hundred then.

lines.speaker: HORTENSIO
lines.text: Content.

lines.speaker: PETRUCHIO
lines.text: A match! 'tis done.

lines.speaker: HORTENSIO
lines.text: Who shall begin?

lines.speaker: LUCENTIO
lines.text:
That will I.
Go, Biondello, bid your mistress come to me.

lines.speaker: BIONDELLO
lines.text: I go.

lines.speaker: BAPTISTA
lines.text: Son, I'll be your half, Bianca comes.

lines.speaker: LUCENTIO
lines.text:
I'll have no halves; I'll bear it all myself.
How now! what news?

lines.speaker: BIONDELLO
lines.text:
Sir, my mistress sends you word
That she is busy and she cannot come.

lines.speaker: PETRUCHIO
lines.text:
How! she is busy and she cannot come!
Is that an answer?

lines.speaker: GREMIO
lines.text:
Ay, and a kind one too:
Pray God, sir, your wife send you not a worse.

lines.speaker: PETRUCHIO
lines.text: I hope better.

lines.speaker: HORTENSIO
lines.text:
Sirrah Biondello, go and entreat my wife
To come to me forthwith.

lines.speaker: PETRUCHIO
lines.text:
O, ho! entreat her!
Nay, then she must needs come.

lines.speaker: HORTENSIO
lines.text:
I am afraid, sir,
Do what you can, yours will not be entreated.
Now, where's my wife?

lines.speaker: BIONDELLO
lines.text:
She says you have some goodly jest in hand:
She will not come: she bids you come to her.

lines.speaker: PETRUCHIO
lines.text:
Worse and worse; she will not come! O vile,
Intolerable, not to be endured!
Sirrah Grumio, go to your mistress;
Say, I command her to come to me.

lines.speaker: HORTENSIO
lines.text: I know her answer.

lines.speaker: PETRUCHIO
lines.text: What?

lines.speaker: HORTENSIO
lines.text: She will not.

lines.speaker: PETRUCHIO
lines.text: The fouler fortune mine, and there an end.

lines.speaker: BAPTISTA
lines.text: Now, by my holidame, here comes Katharina!

lines.speaker: KATHARINA
lines.text: What is your will, sir, that you send for me?

lines.speaker: PETRUCHIO
lines.text: Where is your sister, and Hortensio's wife?

lines.speaker: KATHARINA
lines.text: They sit conferring by the parlor fire.

lines.speaker: PETRUCHIO
lines.text:
Go fetch them hither: if they deny to come.
Swinge me them soundly forth unto their husbands:
Away, I say, and bring them hither straight.

lines.speaker: LUCENTIO
lines.text: Here is a wonder, if you talk of a wonder.

lines.speaker: HORTENSIO
lines.text: And so it is: I wonder what it bodes.

lines.speaker: PETRUCHIO
BAPTISTA
lines.text:
Now, fair befal thee, good Petruchio!
The wager thou hast won; and I will add
Unto their losses twenty thousand crowns;
Another dowry to another daughter,
For she is changed, as she had never been.

lines.speaker: PETRUCHIO
lines.text:
Nay, I will win my wager better yet
And show more sign of her obedience,
Her new-built virtue and obedience.
See where she comes and brings your froward wives
As prisoners to her womanly persuasion.
Katharina, that cap of yours becomes you not:
Off with that bauble, throw it under-foot.
Widow
Lord, let me never have a cause to sigh,
Till I be brought to such a silly pass!

lines.speaker: BIANCA
lines.text: Fie! what a foolish duty call you this?

lines.speaker: LUCENTIO
lines.text:
I would your duty were as foolish too:
The wisdom of your duty, fair Bianca,
Hath cost me an hundred crowns since supper-time.

lines.speaker: BIANCA
lines.text: The more fool you, for laying on my duty.

lines.speaker: PETRUCHIO
lines.text:
Katharina, I charge thee, tell these headstrong women
What duty they do owe their lords and husbands.
Widow
Come, come, you're mocking: we will have no telling.

lines.speaker: PETRUCHIO
lines.text:
Come on, I say; and first begin with her.
Widow
She shall not.

lines.speaker: PETRUCHIO
lines.text: I say she shall: and first begin with her.

lines.speaker: KATHARINA
lines.text:
Fie, fie! unknit that threatening unkind brow,
And dart not scornful glances from those eyes,
To wound thy lord, thy king, thy governor:
It blots thy beauty as frosts do bite the meads,
Confounds thy fame as whirlwinds shake fair buds,
And in no sense is meet or amiable.
A woman moved is like a fountain troubled,
Muddy, ill-seeming, thick, bereft of beauty;
And while it is so, none so dry or thirsty
Will deign to sip or touch one drop of it.
Thy husband is thy lord, thy life, thy keeper,
Thy head, thy sovereign; one that cares for thee,
And for thy maintenance commits his body
To painful labour both by sea and land,
To watch the night in storms, the day in cold,
Whilst thou liest warm at home, secure and safe;
And craves no other tribute at thy hands
But love, fair looks and true obedience;
Too little payment for so great a debt.
Such duty as the subject owes the prince
Even such a woman oweth to her husband;
And when she is froward, peevish, sullen, sour,
And not obedient to his honest will,
What is she but a foul contending rebel
And graceless traitor to her loving lord?
I am ashamed that women are so simple
To offer war where they should kneel for peace;
Or seek for rule, supremacy and sway,
When they are bound to serve, love and obey.
Why are our bodies soft and weak and smooth,
Unapt to toil and trouble in the world,
But that our soft conditions and our hearts
Should well agree with our external parts?
Come, come, you froward and unable worms!
My mind hath been as big as one of yours,
My heart as great, my reason haply more,
To bandy word for word and frown for frown;
But now I see our lances are but straws,
Our strength as weak, our weakness past compare,
That seeming to be most which we indeed least are.
Then vail your stomachs, for it is no boot,
And place your hands below your husband's foot:
In token of which duty, if he please,
My hand is ready; may it do him ease.

lines.speaker: PETRUCHIO
lines.text: Why, there's a wench! Come on, and kiss me, Kate.

lines.speaker: LUCENTIO
lines.text: Well, go thy ways, old lad; for thou shalt ha't.

lines.speaker: VINCENTIO
lines.text: 'Tis a good hearing when children are toward.

lines.speaker: LUCENTIO
lines.text: But a harsh hearing when women are froward.

lines.speaker: PETRUCHIO
lines.text:
Come, Kate, we'll to bed.
We three are married, but you two are sped.
To LUCENTIO
'Twas I won the wager, though you hit the white;
And, being a winner, God give you good night!
Exeunt PETRUCHIO and KATHARINA

lines.speaker: HORTENSIO
lines.text: Now, go thy ways; thou hast tamed a curst shrew.

lines.speaker: LUCENTIO
lines.text:
'Tis a wonder, by your leave, she will be tamed so.
Exeunt
